issues.description: PersonService.getAllPersons has a parameter/signature mismatch between the template/problem specification and the solution. The problem statement (Part 3) and the template expect a single-argument method getAllPersons(PersonSortingOptions sortingOptions) that students must implement to add sorting. The solution, however, changed the service to getAllPersons(PersonSortingOptions sortingOptions, boolean includeInactive) and updated PersonResource to call it with an extra boolean argument. This is a structural mismatch: students following the problem and template will implement a single-argument method and update endpoints accordingly, while the solution demonstrates and relies on a two-argument method. This difference is likely unintentional and will confuse students and automated tests (method not found / incorrect signature).
issues.suggested_fix: Restore a single-argument signature for getAllPersons to match the template/problem (public List<Person> getAllPersons(PersonSortingOptions sortingOptions)) and implement sorting there. Then have PersonResource and PersonController pass only the PersonSortingOptions. Alternatively, if the extra boolean is intentional, update the problem statement and template signatures/instructions to include and explain the boolean parameter (and update the method declaration in the template) so all artifacts agree.

issues.description: The problem statement contains a small but potentially confusing textual mismatch when describing the client-side PersonController behavior: it says "Each method takes a Consumer<List<Note>> parameter" when it should refer to persons (Consumer<List<Person>>). The UML and the code expect Consumer<List<Person>>. This typo could momentarily confuse students implementing the PersonController methods.
issues.suggested_fix: Correct the problem statement text to say "Each method takes a Consumer<List<Person>> parameter" so it consistently matches the UML and the code examples. This removes the minor source of confusion while preserving the exercise intent.
